text: Poured from a 22 oz bottle. It pours a clear yellow/gold color with moderate carbonation and a thin head. I didnt get much of an aroma.. If anything, I thought I got a whiff of butterscotch and I guess some light bread malt. There is some hop bitterness in the flavor, which I like. The body has a nice crispness. This is not the best beer Ive ever had and also not the worst. I would probably buy it at a bar if they had it on draft... depending on what else was available..
Sampler at the source. Pours yellow gold with a white head. Aroma is caramel, wheat. Flavor is caramel, bread, slight citrus, a bit of pepper spice.

Sampled at the brewpub, pours a clear gold with some lacing, ringing white head. Nose has malt, mild perfume, a little grass, some mild melon. Flavor has lemon, straw, some melon again, a little metallic. Watery finish.

Tap at the brewery. Pours clear gold with a small, fizzy white head, short retention with spare lacing. Aroma is sweet corn and Pils malt with earthy and spicy hops. Flavor is malt dominant, Pils malt with light hops and medium bitterness and a dry finish. Light body and moderate carbonation.

Bomber into tulip. Hazy golden yellow, moderate persistent white head. On the nose, Id swear its a hefe -- wheaty, a hint of fruit. In the mouth, its fairly hoppy on the entry, picks up a grainy mid, and finishes with resinous hops. Decent, but Id like the hops dialed back just a bit.

Features the usual light bready aroma and also some spiciness and grass. Lighter yellow, and while heady, its still for a Kolsch Id say. Initial bitterness followed by a sharp dirt finish. Exceptional crispness. What Kolsch needs as a style is more hops...and it;s covered here.

Excellent Kolsch, slightly heavy on bittering hops = perfect. Initial bitterness followed by mild sweetness, finished by a pleasantly lingering bitterness. Great beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Sweet malts and grains. Pale clear gold with a thin bubbly head. Grains, cereal, grassy hops.

On tap at the brewpub.
Comes to the table a lightly hazy gold with a smallish white head that persists. Nice sweet bready pilsner malt nose with a hint of honey and floral spicy hops. The flavor is a touch on the sweet side with an almost under attenuated quality to it. Sweet honey caramel and pilsner malt with a touch of spicy hop and a hint of diacytyl. Light to medium body with a moderate level of carbonation and a sweet bubbly mouthfeel. Its a touch sweet, but I could get behind a few of these.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear light orange with a thin white head. Aroma of light fruits, strawberry, pale malts. Flavor of bready malt, sweet fruit, earthy hops, and more grains the finish. A well made kolsch- complex and not too sweet.
7/4/8/4/14 (3.7/5)
Herbal and citrus aroma, taste is light bitter. Drinkable with long finish.

Sample at the brewpub. Pours a clear straw color with a thin and fizzy white head that evaporates quickly to a film. Spotty lacing on the glass. Aroma of grassy hops and malt. Light body with flavors of mildly bitter hops, biscuit malt and a solvent-like taste in the background. The finish is lightly bitter with a metallic hops aftertaste. Something off about this one.
Wowe. Awesome fresh crisp clean cracker malts. Pleasant herbal wet grass hops. Prickly carbonation. Some rustic dry herbal dough to round things out. Nice juiciness mid palate. Great beer.
To be clear, I had the Kolsch German style ale. Fantastic beer. The aroma is out of this world great. You dont expect this from a golden ale. I have nothing bad to say.

Pours pale yellow into a shaker. Bright white head with good retention recedes leaving spider lacing. Caramel and resin aromas. Dry with sweet caramel and sourdough upfront turning to grapefruit in the lasting pith finish.
On tap at the brewery.  Pours amber.  Aroma of pale and light caramel malts plus some floral hops and bread.  Flavor the same.  Average texture.  A good beer for the style.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2011 What a great kolsch.  I would almost classify this as a pale ale with the amount of hoppy goodness I taste.  Very light crisp refreshing and quite good.  May be the best kolsch Ive ever had.
Fresh lightly hopped aroma, filtered beer. Light pale malts and a very crisp bitter lingering finish.

really surprised i havent rated this before, and even more surprising is the flavor behind this beer. honestly, pours like a macro american adjunct lager, but the taste is nothing like it at all. extremely full bodied for a kolsch, hints of floral and hop notes with a fresh bread-like maltiness that both satisfies and keeps you wanting more. delicious on a hot summer night in Granby.
On Tap C. H. Crisp pour with a nice head. Lots of light malty flavor with a bit of all spice at the end. Very good!

On tap at the brew pub in Granby, CT. Aroma of citrus and hops with a hint of banana. Front palate of orange with hoppy backbone and a bitter finish. Funky aftertaste that definitely depreciates the experience.

En fût. Verre de dégustation directement à la brasserie. Arôme: Odeur de céréales avec une pointe dhoublons floraux. Apparence: La couleur est blonde légèrement voilée avec une moyenne densité de bulle. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de céréales avec une pointe citronnée. Longue durée de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Présence de céréales en arrière goût. (Rating #2960)

UPDATED: APR 6, 2010 My Bottom Line:
Persistent hay and spicy, herbal hops coalesce in this snappy and harmonious Kölsch.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A slice of foam decorates the hazy straw blonde. Head retention could be improved for this to be world-class.
-The nose is more subtle than the flavor profile.
-The smooth effervescence and well rounded body make for a smashing mouthfeel.
-The flavors are well balanced and perfectly structured; a perfect union of authentic ingredients.
-The cereal presence in the flavor profile is stupendous.

On tap at both the Torrington and Granby locations.
Draught. Low and quickly disappearing white head. Ligh clear yellow body. Weak mild honey lemon clove aroma and flavor. Low carbonation and a short aftertaste.

Pours yellowish in coloration, smells sweet, malty, alittle grassy. The taste is sweet, malty, clove and pure delicousness. This isn’t my favorite style by any means but this is by far the best i have tried in this style.

Growler.  Poured an almost clear light yellow color with a large white head.  The aroma had nice floral and earthy notes riding on top of the malt base.  Malty clean flavor.  Bitter finish on a light body.
on tap-pours a retaining thin white head that laces and yellow color.  Aroma is grain, grassy, lemon.  Taste is sweet grain, grassy, lemon/light crisp hops.  Light body.  OK effervescence.

Growler shared by kmweaver.  Hazy brilliant yellow/wheat colored body under a thin white head.  Wonderfully fresh nose of lemon grass, pillowy yeast, wheat, dough, very light, airy and fresh smelling, with a hint of pils crackers malt.  Flavor is mildly sweet, well-balanced, focusing on lemon grass, wheat, more crackers malts, some dough - properly crisp, and the body stands up well as it should in this style.  A very delicious psuedo-Kolsch.

Growler courtesy of kmweaver. Hazy, straw body with a small white head.  Sweet, herbal hose with grass, honey, light lemon and corn sugar. The flavor is moderately sweet with honey, corn sugar, herbs, lots of grass and light oxidation. Light body is round with moderate carbonation.

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2008 Draft, Cambridge House.  Pours an effervescent, hazy straw color; thick, textured white head with beautiful retention and lacing that lasts forever; champagne-like effervescence that constantly replenishes the head; gorgeous pour.  Very pleasant, dry mineral bitterness in the aroma; bone dry, clean, slightly reserved, with a bit of lime or citrus coming through.  Mouthfeel follows suit; dry doughiness at the core, with generous, spritzy mineral and citrus bitterness throughout; perfect feel and mineral dryness in the mouth; generous bitterness without becoming chewy; an awesome, flawless Kölsch.  Medium, dry finish, with lingering mineral bitterness and biscuity notes.

12oz hand bottled by Dickinsonbeer, thanks to Paul.  Dude just pulls this out for fun before a casual 4th hangout.  fluffy white head, tall and rocky.  color is clear bright gold, fizz up the center.  aroma is mild fresh grass, very light floral honey like clover.  dry pale malt aroma too.  flavor is very crisp and clean, sweet white sugar then malt goes pale and dryish, dry grassy.  finish and aftertaste is sweet again, back to crisp and dry again.  pentultimate yard work beer!

12oz hand bottled by Dickinsonbeer, thanks Paul.  Pours a clear soft honey golden with some faint pinkish highlights and a one finger white head with tiny tiny bubbles, decent retention.  Aroma of sugar cookies, bready malts, grassy and lightly earthy hops--fairly sweet overall.  Lots of sugar cookie and bread doughy malts, light grain, and a fair amount of bitterness (4 out of 10) from the grassy and earthy hops.  I even got a hint of lemon somewhere.  Dry finish with no lingering bitterness.  Mouthfeel is creamy with soft light to moderate carbonation.  This was very enjoyable and so easy drinking that the bottle was gone within 10 or 12 minutes, and I was trying to pace myself.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Bottle shared with willblake and Dickinsonbeer. Poured a clear golden/yellow with a small white head. Aroma was a musty hops with a bready maly yeastienss. Flavor was very crisp with a light hops prescence and the palate was smooth and crisp with a light body. This was a very nice easy drinking beer overall.

Draft... GABF 06... Clear, light yellow ale with a small, white head. Subdued, grainy, diacetylic aroma. Tangy, lightly malty flavor with notes of cereal grain and butterscotch. Medium-bodied and lightly creamy with moderate carbonation. Finishes crisp and dry.

If you served this to me right in the center of Cologne, Id have no idea it was an American production, and Id rate it up there with the best 3 or 4 that Ive enjoyed. Really quite authentic tasting, the first American Kolsch that is a true Kolsch. The pour was alarming in a pint glass (wheres my stange?) and the head wasnt as fluffy and pretty as it should have been. However, the aroma was rich and awesome, good musty (even wood-like, not sure if they age this in wood barrels or not), light honey, and light bready character. The flavor captured all of that and presented a nicely balanced beer, somewhat dry and carbonated finish, far superior to the "big" Cologne products like Sion or Dom. One of my favorite recent beer experiences.

BCTC thanks to DYC for the growler.  Perfect beer to start out a hot day on the day before the fest.  Pours a light chill haze, then clears as it warms and a thin lasting head and good lacing.  Aroma is lightly fruity, some herbal and spicy hints and even some nice noble hops.  Lightly sweet malt, herbal and flowery with a light refreshing spice.  Nice hoppy bitter finish.  Very refreshing and delicate beer.  Awesome Kolsch.

07.14.06  From growler, thanks to DYC, BCTC.  Golden stuff, maybe a touch of green tint, maybe thats the grass that surrounds us.  Theres something perfect about drinking a Kolsch in the middle of a field as the aromas of grasses and grains surrounding me compliment the well rounded and superbly bread doughy malts in this beer.  Quickly fading white head was initially lofty and laces.  Creamy stuff, bursting grain fruits in every sip, zero bitterness.  Finish is a ghost, as it leaves barely a trace of itself behind on the palate.  What a quencher.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a crisp, clean yellow color. The taste is light and refreshing but rich; flavors of lemongrass, hay, and some apple too. This is bone dry; it finishes as clean as it looks. 5.1 ABV isnt high, but whats there is undetectable. Malt isnt too prominent here, but enough to give it some weight and help balance out the hops. Kolsch isnt my favorite style, but I tried it after seeing the high style percentile rating. I was not disappointed; this is a tasty and satisfying light beer.

And Chris says: "Mmmmm"

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2006 Growler samples from DYCSoccer at BCTC 06.Medium clarity, nice to see some slight haziness, enough to signify low filtration.  Warm honey-toned is the brassy-gold body.  Plastered atop is a small but very stable white head that seems immovable.  Wispy lacing is quite apparent.The nose explodes with a perfect combination of Cologne yeast, lightly papery, hints of chalk and light sulfates with a touch of apple skin.  Pear skin is overlaid on top and you get an almost extremely-dry-chardonnay-effect.  So immensely crisp I can barely remember any more snappy an aroma than this.  Hops are dry, grassy and herbal.  Well done to style and just dripping with aromatics.  Only the slightest bit of honey seeps through, but it is just enough to suggest balance.  Dry biscuits progress as it warms, lightly grainy and further adding dryness.  It never gets too dry though, as the light sweetness on the end and the dry green and yellow fruit-notes are well-balanced.  No alcohol whatsoever, and just a study in Cologne yeast.The light pils malt in the aroma translates a bit more in to the flavor.  As I take a sip, the tongue is lightly washed in honey, but nearly immediately, the hops add a subtle herbal note as the yeast crackles with snappy, flavorful dryness.  More pear skin and fresh white grape-notes slowly transition in to a hint of slight caramel and a touch of chewy, moist biscuits.  Tight, low carbonation completes the picture.  Im on the fence with the palate score.  It seems there is a slight bit of vapidity on the end and the yeast crispness seems to falter slightly, whereas I would envision a finish and aftertaste with heavy crisp dryness.  I could see a touch of lactic-like notes adding a bit more depth, but this is extreme criticism and would be extremely difficult to replicate.  Anyways, one hell of an authentic Kolsch.  Not thin in the least.For me personally, its satisfying to see the brewer from the first brewpub I started drinking beer at make a top- notch beer like this.  Not that I ever doubted he could.  Hes come a long way from Skaneateles Light.  Thanks again for bringing this, Casey.
Thanks to DYCsoccer for bringing a growler of this to BCTC.  Nose is lemon, hay,grass.  Not super complex but great.  Flavor is super light pils malt, grassy hops, so light, so perfect.

A bit unusual to find this type of beer around this time of the year, but oh well.  Pours yellow/white with a thin white head.  Smells of grapes and lemons.  Taste is light straw with some decent hints of lemon.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2008 (2/19/08, growler, thanks kmweaver) Hazy lemon yellow body with white head.  Aroma is medium sweet, lemon, straw.  Taste is medium sweet, straw, some lemon, hay.  Light body, somewhat watery.  (5/3/7/3/13)

(12/31/05, draft) Hazy straw body with white head.  Aroma is medium sweet4, lemon.  Taste is medium sweet, lemon/grassy, biscuit, light floral.  Light-medium body, some crispness. (4/3/7/4/14)
Growler  Golden in color with a large white head. Aroma of floral hops and light malt. Clean crisp finish, light citrus fruit character.One of the better American versions Ive had.
On tap at the brewpub. Yellow in color with a little head. Fruity hoppy aroma. Citrusy. Hoppy and malty flavor. Nice hop bitterness. Finish is hoppy. Light and refreshing. Enjoyable.
Tap at the brewpub. Hazy yellow, thin white head. Hoppy fruity aroma, with a little pale maltiness. Thin pale malt flavors with plenty of hop flavor and nice bitterness. Hoppy fruity finish.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: UPDATED: OCT 28, 2005 Draught @ the Brewpub:  This one pours a hazy, golden color.  There was a decent amount of a white head on it, with a bit of lacing.  There is a bit of lemon to the nose.  There is also faint hints of spiciness and grainy.  The body is a little lighter, with a hint of lemon.  No real bitterness at all.  A very refreshing beer.  Nice for an afternoon on the deck!

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2006 Draft last weekend at the brewpub.  5.1%  Sour, lemony aroma with an astringency in the nose.  Mild grainy characteristics.  Mildly hazy straw color with a frothy white head and pretty lacing.  Light, crisp, slightly lemony to start.  A bit of graininess in the middle.  Extremely creamy and smooth.  A very well done Kolsch.  Extremely drinkable.  Quality stuff.  Rating update------I have had this about half a dozen times since the original rating and this beer consistently gets better every time I have it.  Most likely due to brewer familiarity with his equipment.  A magnificent beer.
